Award.AwardTitle: Northeast LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Northeast Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (NELSAMP) has chosen the University of Connecticut (UConn) as the site for the 2014-2016 Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity. The UConn BD Activity will demonstrate that a proactive, intensive, results-oriented campaign to recruit, prepare, mentor, train, and support doctoral candidates from traditionally underrepresented populations in the STEM disciplines will contribute to resolving social, economic, and technological challenges that currently face the United States. For the U.S. to remain competitive globally, it must provide exceptional educational preparedness in STEM areas that underpin the knowledge-based economy. Students from underrepresented groups in STEM are a critical piece in solving the ongoing puzzle of how to reinvigorate the nation's global technological primacy.

UConn will recruit and support 12 doctoral students from African American, Hispanic and/or Native American populations who are graduates of LSAMP Alliance institutions with BD Fellowships for the first two years of their graduate studies in STEM disciplines at UConn. Structured activities for the BD Fellows include developing focused plans of study and detailed roadmaps of academic milestones; participating in professional skills development workshops; having opportunities for mentorship/volunteering; and receiving career preparation. In addition, UConn will refine and expand its Husky Bridge to the Doctorate STEM Program website. Through innovative STEM research projects in cutting-edge areas such as biomedical engineering, environmental and human sustainability, and nanotechnology, UConn will train outstanding scientists and engineers. The diversity of perspectives, backgrounds, and experiences of the BD Fellows will contribute toward breakthroughs in meeting society's grand challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Program: National Science Foundation (NSF) Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity
Award Number: 1400382

Awardee: University of Connecticut
Program Evaluation period: 2014 - 2017
Report prepared by: Manisha Srivastava, SurePath Evaluations LLC

The University of Connecticut (UConn), a senior representative of the Northeast Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (NELSAMP), was awarded $986,990 through the Bridge to the Doctorate Activity (BD Activity) to support 12 graduate students from African American, Hispanic and/or Native American populations during the first two years of their studies in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) subjects at UConn. The BD funding enables UConn to expand and concentrate the NELSAMP’s continuing efforts to increase the number of qualified students pursuing and completing advanced degrees in STEM areas. The premise for BD funding is that the diversity of perspectives, backgrounds and experiences of the BD Fellows affords new avenues for resolving social, economic and technological challenges that currently limit the U.S. This proactive, intensive, results-oriented campaign to recruit, prepare, mentor, train and support doctoral candidates from traditionally underrepresented populations in the STEM areas is specifically tailored to help foster major breakthroughs in meeting some of society’s challenges.

The suite of activities offered through the BD Activity include cohort meetings among BD Program participants, focused plans of study and detailed roadmaps of academic milestones, K-12 mentoring/outreach opportunities, career preparation, and professional development instruction in teaching, communication and research ethics. The BD Activity also supports the development of a dedicated Husky STEM BD website containing informative material describing the BD Activity, FAQs, a schedule of planned activities, and short summaries of prospective BD research projects and faculty advisors.

BD Faculty Advisors are required not only to advise the BD Fellows but also to serve as engaged, hands-on mentors. BD Advisors commit to fostering their Fellow’s participation in skills-building workshops and training courses, as well as to provide financial support beyond the two-year BD funding period.

UConn recently successfully concluded a BD Activity at UConn (award 1249283). NSF provided UConn funding for a second round of BD, which officially enrolled its first students in the fall of 2014.

The BD program officially began in the fall of 2014, with five Fellows enrolled. By the fall of 2015 the BD program was fully implemented with twelve Fellows enrolled. 

In total, the BD Activity has served 14 Fellows, with 12 Fellows completing the BD Activity. One fellow left after the first semester in graduate school due to family issues, one graduated with Master’s degree at the end of 3rd semesters in graduate school and BD program.
